title: A baker's dozen of Bidenisms
text:
A baker's dozen of Bidenisms Dwight Adams , dwight.adams@indystar.com 6:22 p.m. EDT October 21, 2015 Vice President Joe Biden says he won't run for president in 2016. But that doesn't mean we won't hear more verbal gems like these. Buy Photo The ever-expressive Vice President Joe Biden gestures as he speaks to workers at Ener1's Greenfield plant, which makes advance lithium ion batteries for electric cars, on Jan. 26, 2011. (Photo: Charlie Nye/The Star 2011 file photo) Buy Photo 
If you haven't heard yet, Vice President Joe Biden isn't running for president in 2016. 
Biden unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination in 1988 and 2008. 
Whether or not you think another run would have been a good idea, there's no question he's entertained and perplexed — and maybe even infuriated — many of us with his comments over the past decade or so. 
Here are just a few: Buy Photo 
Vice President Joe Biden asks a question of Roy Blessinger, center, an employee of the Ener1 plant in Greenfield, Ind., that produces advance lithium ion batteries for the Think City electric car going into production in Elkhart. Biden toured the plant on Wednesday, Jan. 26, 2011. (Photo: Charlie Nye/The Star 2011 file photo) 
1) Auto industry 
"You don't have to be a fortune teller to see which way the auto industry is going to go." 
— Addressing a group of workers at EnerDel, a high-tech battery plant in Greenfield, Ind., that Biden visited in January 2011 on a tour to boost clean energy. 
2) Vice presidency 
"My mother believed and my father believed that if I wanted to be president of the United States, I could be, I could be Vice President!" 
— About serving as vice president, which John Nance Garner (Franklin Delano Roosevelt's vice president from 1933 to 1941) once described as "not worth a bucket of warm spit.” 
3) Social gaffe <!--iframe--> 
"Stand up, Chuck, let 'em see ya." 
— In nod to Missouri State Sen. Chuck Graham, who is in a wheelchair, in Columbia, Mo., on Sept. 12, 2008. 
4) Misnaming a justice 
"Jill (Biden's wife) and I had the great honor of standing on that stage, looking across at one of the great justices, Justice Stewart." 
— Mistakenly referring to U.S. Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens, who swore him in as vice president on Jan. 20, 2009. The Enquirer/Cara Owsley Fullscreen Pope Francis addresses a joint meeting of the U.S. Congress with with Vice President Joe Biden (L) and Speaker of the House John Boehner (R-OH) in the House Chamber of the U.S. Capitol on September 24, 2015 in Washington, DC. Pope Francis is the first pope to address a joint meeting of Congress and will finish his tour of Washington. Photo by Mark Wilson/Getty Images Fullscreen Vice President Joe Biden speaks at a White House Champions of Change Law Enforcement and Youth meeting, in the South Court Auditorium of the Eisenhower Executive Office Building on the White House complex in Washington. CNN said Monday, Sept. 28, 2015, it will allow Biden to participate in the first Democratic presidential primary debate even if he decides that day to be a candidate.
